description: From Middle English dower, dowere, from Old French doeire, from Medieval Latin dōtārium, from Latin dōs.

entries.meaning: (law) The part of or interest in a deceased husband's property provided to his widow, usually in the form of a life estate.
(law) Property given by a groom directly to his bride at or before their wedding in order to legitimize the marriage; dowry.
(obsolete) That with which one is gifted or endowed; endowment; gift.
examples: How great, how plentiful, how rich a dower!

verbs.description: dower (third-person singular simple present dowers, present participle dowering, simple past and past participle dowered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a dower or dowry to.
examples: He had married a lady well educated and softly nurtured, but not dowered with worldly wealth.
